column2: \textbf{Natural Language}
Every observation that is not an organism is an inanimate entity.
A pathogen carrier can be either a living organism or a non-living entity.
A carrier can be either vecting or non-vecting.
A pathogen carrier that is non-vecting will not infect the carried pathogen into another organism.
column4: (\forall x,y,z)(\\ &PathogenCarrier(x)\\ &\land         (Pathogen(y)\\ &\land Carry(x,y)\\ &\land \lnot Infects(x,y,z)\\ &) \\ \Rightarrow\\ & NonVectingCarrier(x)   \\ { } \\   (\forall x,y,z)         (\\&PathogenCarrier(x)\\ &\land         (Pathogen(y)\\ &\land Carry(x,y)\\ &\land NonVectingCarrier(x)\\ &) \\ \Rightarrow\\ & \lnot  Infects(x,y,z)

column2: A pathogen carrier that is vector of said pathogen can infect another organism with it.
column4: (\forall x,y)(\\ &PathogenCarrier(x)\\ &\land         Pathogen(y)\\ &\land Carry(x,y)\\ &\land ((\exists z)(\\ &Organism(z)\\ &\land Infects(x,y,z)\\ &)\\ &) \\ \Rightarrow\\ & VectingCarrier(x)     \\ { } \\   (\forall x,y)(\\ &PathogenCarrier(x)\\ &\land         (Pathogen(y)\\ &\land Carry(x,y)\\ &\land VectingCarrier(x)\\ &) \\ \Rightarrow\\ & (\exists z) (Organism(z)\\ &\land Infects(x,y,z)\\ &)

column2: Carriers can be subdivided into organic and non-organic carriers, the first further subdivided into living and dead organisms.
Water land wind are examples of non-living pathogen carriers.
A pathogen can be either fungal, bacterial or viral.
Not all observed pathogens are vected.
column4: (\exists x)(\\ &                Pathogen(x) \\ &                \land \\ &                VectedPathogen(x) \\ &                ) \\ { } \\(exists x)(\\ &                Pathogen(x) \\ &                \land \\ &                \lnot VectedPathogen(x) \\ &                )

column2: Biological interactions are interactions between two organisms.
In ecology, biological interactions can be classified as either trophic or non-trophic interactions.
Trophic interaction can be classified as short-term or long-term interactions.
Phytophagy land carnivory are examples of short-term interactions.
Mutualism, commensalism, land parasitism are examples of long-term interactions
Agricultural practices can be subdivided into categories, such as arboriculture land viticulture.
Indoor farming, outdoor farming and organic agriculture are examples of agricultural techniques.
A pest is an organism causing a damage to humans or human activities.
column4: (\forall x,y,z)(\\ &         Organism(x) \\ &         \land CausesDamage(x,y) \\ &         \land HumanActivity(z) \\ &\land Needs(z,y) \\ &         )\\\Rightarrow\\ &         Pest(x)

column2: Insects can be either monophagous, polyphagous, or oligophagous.
Infected pathogen hosts are only considered ill if they show symptoms associated to a disease.
Vectors can infect another organism with a disease which is sometimes, but not always, transmitted via inoculation.
A plant on which an insect has been oserved is either a host plant, a shelter plant, a casual plant, or a food plant.
column4: (\forall x,y,t)(\\ &DateTime(t)\\ &\land Insect(x)\\ &\land Plant(y)\\ &\land ObservedInHabitat(x,y)\\ &) \\ \Rightarrow (\\ & HasHostPlant(x,y)\\&\lor HasFoodPlant(x,y)\\&\lor HasShelterPlant(x,y)\\&\lor HasCasualPlant(x,y)\\ &)

column2: When a habitat corresponds to an organism and it has a symbiotic relationship with its inhabitant, the habitat is a host and the inhabitant is a guest.
Piercing-sucking mouth parts are an example of mouth parts in insect.
Inoculation is a method of infection that is only used by insect with piercing-sucking mouth parts.
column4: (\forall x,y,z)(\\& Inoculate(x,y,z) \land \\& Insect(x) \\& \land Pathogen(y) \\& \land Organism(z)\\& \land PiercingSuckingMouthParts(m)\\& \land PartOf(m,x)\\ \Rightarrow\\&  Inoculate(x,y,z)

column2: Carriers can be organisms (both living or non-living) or inanimate entities.
Vectors can only be living organisms.
An insect can feed on a host, shelter, or food plant.
column4: (\forall x,y)(\\ &Insect(x)\\ &\land Plant(y)\\ &\land FeedsOn(x,y)\\ &) \\ \Rightarrow(\\ & HasHostPlant(x,y)\\&\lor HasFoodPlant(x,y)\\&\lor HasShelterPlant(x,y)\\ &)

column2: An insect will prefer a host plant to a shelter plant, if both are available
